overview.content: Pavlof is an active stratovolcano rising to 2,493 m (8,179 ft) on the Alaska Peninsula in the United States, approximately 950 km (590 mi) southwest of Anchorage. It is the most active volcano in the Aleutian volcanic arc and one of the most frequently erupting volcanoes in North America, with 48 recorded eruptions since 1762 — an average of roughly one eruption every 5.4 years. Pavlof forms a dramatic pair of symmetrical, glacier-clad cones with the adjacent Pavlof Sister to the northeast, overlooking Pavlof Bay and the Bering Sea. The volcano is part of the Aleutian volcanic arc, generated by the subduction of the Pacific Plate beneath the North American Plate at a rate of approximately 65-75 mm per year. This arc extends approximately 2,500 km from mainland Alaska through the Aleutian Islands and contains more than 40 active volcanoes, making it one of the most volcanically active chains in the Ring of Fire. Pavlof was constructed along a line of vents extending northeast from the Emmons Lake caldera, a large Quaternary caldera system at the base of the volcano. While Pavlof's remote location means it poses minimal direct risk to human populations — the nearest community, Cold Bay, has approximately 100 residents and lies 60 km away — the volcano is a significant aviation hazard. The North Pacific Great Circle air routes, which carry approximately 50,000 commercial flights per year between North America and East Asia, pass directly over or near the Aleutian arc. Pavlof's frequent eruptions make it a regular source of ash-cloud advisories and flight reroutings. The volcano is monitored around the clock by the Alaska Volcano Observatory (AVO), a partnership of the USGS, the University of Alaska Fairbanks (UAF), and the Alaska Division of Geological and Geophysical Surveys (ADGGS).

geology_and_formation.content: Pavlof is a Holocene stratovolcano built primarily of alternating layers of andesitic to basaltic-andesitic lava flows, pyroclastic deposits, and volcanic ash. It was constructed along a northeast-trending line of vents extending from the Emmons Lake caldera, a large (~15 km diameter) Quaternary caldera that represents an older, larger volcanic system. Pavlof Sister, a nearly identical but significantly less active cone located just 10 km to the northeast, was built along the same structural trend. The Aleutian volcanic arc forms where the Pacific Plate, moving northwest at 65-75 mm per year, plunges beneath the North American Plate along the Alaska-Aleutian megathrust — one of the most seismically and volcanically active plate boundaries on Earth. The subducting plate releases water and other volatiles as it descends, lowering the melting point of the overlying mantle wedge and generating magma that rises to feed the arc's volcanoes. Pavlof's andesitic to basaltic-andesitic composition is typical of arc volcanoes and produces eruptions ranging from effusive lava flows to moderately explosive Strombolian and Vulcanian events. Little Pavlof, a smaller parasitic cone on the southwest flank near the rim of Emmons Lake caldera, has not erupted historically. Pavlof's active summit vents lie near the top of the cone on the north and east sides, and eruptions typically produce lava fountaining, Strombolian explosions, ash columns, and lava flows that descend the glacier-covered flanks, often generating lahars when hot volcanic material melts snow and ice. The volcano's nearly perfect conical symmetry — comparable to that of Mount Fuji or Mayon — reflects relatively uniform eruption rates and vent stability over time.

eruption_history_overview.content:
Pavlof's recorded eruptive history begins in 1762 and includes 48 documented eruptions through 2022 — the most of any volcano in the Aleutian arc. Prior to European observation (the first Russian fur-trading expeditions reached the area in the mid-18th century), Pavlof's eruption record is unknown, though the well-constructed cone indicates a lengthy Holocene eruptive history. The 1762 eruption, possibly extending to 1786, was the largest recorded (VEI 4), though details are sparse due to the remoteness of the region at that time.

Eruptions have been particularly frequent since the mid-19th century, with multiple eruptions per decade commonplace throughout the 20th and 21st centuries. Activity is typically Strombolian to Vulcanian in character: lava fountaining and explosive bursts from summit vents send ash columns to altitudes of 5,000-12,000 m (15,000-40,000 ft), generate incandescent lava flows down the flanks, and produce lahars. The largest 20th-century eruptions (VEI 3) occurred in 1906-1911, 1936-1948, 1974-1975, 1980-1981, 1983, 1986-1988, and 2013-2014. Individual eruptions typically last days to weeks, though some episodes have persisted for years.

subsections.title: The 1762-1786 Eruption — Largest Recorded Event (VEI 4)
subsections.content: The earliest recorded eruption of Pavlof, and the largest in its known history, began in 1762 and may have continued intermittently until 1786. This VEI 4 event was observed by early Russian explorers and fur traders, though accounts are limited in detail given the extreme remoteness of the region. The eruption produced significant explosive activity and is inferred to have generated substantial ash columns and pyroclastic deposits. The 24-year duration attributed to this event may represent multiple discrete eruptions that early observers could not distinguish. Regardless, the VEI 4 rating indicates a significant eruption — comparable in scale to the 2010 eruption of Eyjafjallajökull — that would cause major aviation disruption if it occurred today.

subsections.title: The 1906-1911 Eruption — Fissure Opening on the North Flank
subsections.content: The most significant eruption of the early 20th century began in 1906 and continued through 1911. Rated VEI 3, this eruption culminated in a dramatic event in 1911 when a fissure opened on the north flank of the volcano, ejecting large blocks and producing lava flows that descended toward Pavlof Bay. This was the largest effusive event in Pavlof's recorded history and demonstrated the volcano's capacity for flank eruptions in addition to its typical summit activity. The north flank fissure eruption also generated significant lahars as lava interacted with glacial ice.

subsections.title: The 1986-1988 Eruption — Sustained Multi-Year Activity
subsections.content: One of Pavlof's longest-sustained eruption episodes began in 1986 and continued through 1988. Rated VEI 3, the eruption produced vigorous Strombolian and Vulcanian activity from northeast and southeast summit vents and flanks. Ash columns repeatedly reached 6,000-10,000 m altitude, triggering numerous aviation advisories and flight diversions across the North Pacific. Lava flows descended the northeast and southeast flanks, generating lahars that reached the coast. This eruption provided some of the first detailed instrumental monitoring data for Pavlof, as AVO expanded its monitoring network across the Aleutian arc during the 1980s.

subsections.title: The 2013-2016 Eruptions — Rapid-Onset Events
subsections.content: Pavlof produced a series of eruptions between 2013 and 2016 that highlighted the volcano's capacity for rapid-onset activity. The 2013 eruption (VEI 3) began with little precursory seismic warning, sending an ash cloud to approximately 8,500 m (28,000 ft) within hours and triggering aviation alerts across the North Pacific. The 2014 eruption consisted of two distinct VEI 3 events, including a November episode that again produced ash columns reaching 9,000 m and caused significant flight rerouting. A smaller VEI 2 eruption in March 2016 continued the pattern. These eruptions demonstrated a challenge that Pavlof poses for eruption forecasting: unlike many volcanoes that produce days to weeks of precursory earthquakes, Pavlof can transition from background seismicity to full eruption in hours, limiting warning time.

subsections.title: The 2021-2022 Eruption — Most Recent Activity
subsections.content: The most recent eruption of Pavlof began in August 2021 and continued intermittently into 2022. The eruption produced lava fountaining, Strombolian explosions, and ash emissions from the summit vents, with ash clouds reaching altitudes of approximately 4,500-6,000 m (15,000-20,000 ft). Lava flows descended the northeast and east flanks, generating minor lahars. AVO maintained elevated alert levels (aviation color code Orange to Red) through much of the eruption. The eruption was typical of Pavlof's modern activity — moderate in scale but persistent and frequent enough to require ongoing monitoring and aviation coordination.

current_status_and_monitoring.content:
Pavlof is currently at normal background levels following the 2021-2022 eruption, though given its eruption frequency — 48 eruptions in 260 years — another eruption could begin at any time, potentially with very little warning. The Alaska Volcano Observatory (AVO) maintains continuous monitoring of Pavlof using a network of seismometers installed on and around the volcano, supplemented by infrasound detectors (which can detect explosive eruptions at great distances), satellite-based thermal monitoring, webcams, and periodic overflights. The current aviation color code is Green (normal background activity).

One of the key monitoring challenges at Pavlof is the volcano's tendency for rapid-onset eruptions. Several recent eruptions have initiated with minimal precursory seismic activity, transitioning from quiet to full eruption in hours rather than the days or weeks typical of many other volcanoes. AVO has invested in improving real-time monitoring capabilities specifically because of this challenge. The observatory maintains a 24/7 watch capability and issues Volcanic Activity Notices (VANs) and Volcanic Ash Advisories (VAAs) in coordination with the National Weather Service's Volcanic Ash Advisory Center in Anchorage.

hazards_and_risk_assessment.content: Pavlof's primary hazard is to aviation. The North Pacific Great Circle routes — the shortest paths between major North American cities (Los Angeles, San Francisco, Seattle, New York) and East Asian destinations (Tokyo, Seoul, Shanghai, Hong Kong) — pass directly over or near the Aleutian volcanic arc. Approximately 50,000 commercial flights per year traverse this airspace, carrying millions of passengers. Volcanic ash at cruising altitudes (9,000-12,000 m) can cause engine failure, windshield abrasion, and sensor malfunction in jet aircraft. Pavlof's frequent eruptions and tendency to produce ash columns reaching these altitudes make it one of the most operationally significant volcanic hazards in the Pacific region. Ground-level hazards near Pavlof include pyroclastic flows and surges, lava flows, tephra fall, ballistic projectiles, and lahars generated when erupted material melts glacial ice and snow on the volcano's flanks. These lahars can travel tens of kilometers down valley systems to the coast. However, the nearest inhabited community — Cold Bay, with approximately 100 permanent residents — lies about 60 km to the southwest, largely beyond the range of most hazards. King Cove (~900 residents) is approximately 50 km to the south. Ashfall from larger eruptions can reach these communities, causing minor disruption but rarely posing life-threatening hazards. Compared to other Aleutian volcanoes, Pavlof erupts more frequently but generally at lower VEI levels than volcanoes such as Novarupta (whose 1912 VEI 6 eruption was the largest of the 20th century) or Okmok (VEI 4 in 2008). Pavlof's consistent, moderate-level activity makes it a chronic hazard management challenge rather than a catastrophic risk.

geography_and_physical_description.content:
Pavlof is one of the most visually striking volcanoes in Alaska — a near-perfectly symmetrical, glacier-sheathed cone rising steeply to 2,493 m (8,179 ft) from the Alaska Peninsula lowlands. Together with the adjacent Pavlof Sister (2,142 m / 7,028 ft) to the northeast, the two cones create a dramatic twin-peaked silhouette visible across Pavlof Bay and from the Bering Sea. Little Pavlof, a smaller parasitic cone, sits on Pavlof's southwest flank near the rim of the Emmons Lake caldera.

The volcano is extensively glaciated, with ice covering much of the upper cone. The active vents lie near the summit on the north and east sides, and eruption products are channeled down glacial valleys, creating the interaction between hot volcanic material and ice that generates lahars. The summit area contains multiple vents rather than a single well-defined crater, reflecting shifting eruption loci over time.

The surrounding landscape is quintessential Alaska Peninsula terrain: treeless tundra, marshy lowlands, coastal bluffs, and cold-water bays. The climate is maritime subarctic, with strong winds, frequent fog and rain, and heavy winter snowfall. Visibility is often poor, which complicates visual monitoring and aviation advisories. Pavlof Bay to the south and the Bering Sea to the north frame the volcano's flanks.

climate_and_global_impact.content: Pavlof's historical eruptions have not produced measurable global climate effects. Its typical VEI 2-3 eruptions inject ash and SO2 into the troposphere rather than the stratosphere, limiting their atmospheric residence time and climate impact. The VEI 4 eruption of 1762 may have reached the lower stratosphere, but any climate signal from this event is undetectable in historical or proxy records. Pavlof's significance to the global climate discussion is primarily as a representative example of the cumulative atmospheric contribution of frequently erupting arc volcanoes. While individual eruptions are climate-neutral, the aggregate SO2 and aerosol output from the Aleutian arc (including Pavlof, Sheveluch, Klyuchevskoy, and others) contributes to the background volcanic aerosol loading of the upper troposphere and lower stratosphere — a factor that climate models must account for.

cultural_significance.content:
Pavlof takes its name from the Russian naming convention prevalent across Alaska, likely honoring Saint Paul (Pavel in Russian) — reflecting the Russian colonial era when fur traders and Orthodox missionaries established settlements across the Aleutian region in the 18th and 19th centuries. The indigenous Unangan (Aleut) people, who have inhabited the Alaska Peninsula and Aleutian Islands for thousands of years, would have witnessed Pavlof's eruptions throughout their history, though specific indigenous names and oral traditions relating to the volcano are not well documented in published literature.

In modern Alaska, Pavlof is recognized as one of the state's most iconic volcanoes. Its frequent eruptions make it a regular feature in local and national news coverage, and its near-perfect conical shape is frequently photographed and featured in travel and nature media. The volcano is within the Alaska Peninsula National Wildlife Refuge, one of the largest protected areas in the United States, though access is extremely limited due to remoteness and lack of infrastructure.

visiting_and_tourism.content:
Pavlof is one of the most remote major volcanoes in the United States, and visiting it is a serious wilderness expedition rather than a typical tourist outing. There are no trails, roads, or facilities anywhere near the volcano. Access is by bush plane or boat to the Alaska Peninsula, followed by overland travel across roadless tundra. The nearest community with scheduled air service is Cold Bay, approximately 60 km southwest, which has a small airport (originally built as a World War II military base) with irregular flights from Anchorage.

The volcano is occasionally visited by mountaineers, volcanologists, and adventure photographers, but the combination of extreme weather, glacier travel, active volcanic hazards, and brown bear country makes Pavlof an undertaking for experienced wilderness travelers only. For most people interested in viewing Pavlof, the best option is scenic flights from Cold Bay or King Cove, which can offer spectacular aerial views on clear days.

Pavlof sits within the Alaska Peninsula National Wildlife Refuge, managed by the U.S. Fish and Wildlife Service. No permits are required for visiting, but there are no services, and self-sufficiency in food, shelter, navigation, and emergency communication is mandatory.

nearby_volcanoes.content: Pavlof is one of more than 40 active volcanoes along the Aleutian volcanic arc, the northernmost segment of the Ring of Fire. Its immediate neighbor, Pavlof Sister (2,142 m), is a nearly identical but far less active cone to the northeast — it has not erupted in historical times. To the southwest, the Emmons Lake caldera represents a much older and larger volcanic system from which Pavlof's vent lineament extends. Other notable volcanoes on the Alaska Peninsula include Veniaminof, a massive glacier-filled caldera approximately 200 km to the northeast; Novarupta/Katmai, site of the largest eruption of the 20th century (VEI 6, 1912), approximately 400 km northeast; and Shishaldin, the highest peak in the Aleutian Islands (2,857 m), approximately 90 km to the southwest on Unimak Island. The United States has 165 Holocene volcanoes in total, with the vast majority (over 80) in Alaska.

etymology.content: The name 'Pavlof' derives from Russian and is likely a topographic attribution honoring Saint Paul (Russian: Павел, Pavel). During the Russian colonial period in Alaska (roughly 1733-1867), geographic features throughout the territory were commonly named after Russian Orthodox saints, expeditionary leaders, and ships. The spelling 'Pavlof' follows the French-influenced transliteration conventions common in early Russian cartography of the Pacific. Pavlof Bay, at the base of the volcano, shares the name.

facts: Pavlof is the most active volcano in the Aleutian arc, with 48 recorded eruptions since 1762 — an average of one eruption roughly every 5.4 years.
Several of Pavlof's recent eruptions have begun with virtually no seismic precursors, transitioning from background quiet to full eruption in just hours — a major challenge for eruption forecasting.

Approximately 50,000 commercial flights per year cross airspace potentially affected by eruptions from Aleutian arc volcanoes like Pavlof, carrying millions of passengers between North America and East Asia.
Pavlof and Pavlof Sister form one of the most visually striking volcano pairs in the world — two nearly symmetrical, glacier-clad cones rising side by side above the Alaska Peninsula.
Despite being Alaska's most frequently erupting volcano, Pavlof has never caused a recorded human fatality — a testament to its extreme remoteness.
The 1906-1911 eruption included a north-flank fissure event that ejected large blocks and produced lava flows — the most voluminous effusive activity in the volcano's recorded history.
Cold Bay Airport, the nearest airfield to Pavlof, was originally built in 1942 as Fort Randall, a World War II military base — its runway is one of the longest in Alaska.
Pavlof's glacier-covered flanks ensure that virtually every eruption generates lahars (volcanic mudflows) as hot material melts snow and ice.
The volcano was constructed along a vent lineament extending from the Emmons Lake caldera, a much larger and older volcanic system at its southwestern base.
In 2014, Pavlof produced two separate VEI 3 eruptions in a single calendar year — in June and November — demonstrating its capacity for repeated rapid-onset activity.
Pavlof's summit vents have shifted position over time, migrating primarily between the north and east sides of the cone, but the volcano has maintained its remarkably symmetrical profile.

The Alaska Volcano Observatory monitors Pavlof around the clock using seismometers, infrasound detectors, satellite thermal imaging, and webcams — one of the most extensively instrumented remote volcanoes in the world.

faqs.question: Is Pavlof the most active volcano in Alaska?
faqs.answer: Pavlof is the most frequently erupting volcano in the Aleutian arc and one of the most active in all of Alaska, with 48 recorded eruptions since 1762. It erupts on average roughly once every 5.4 years, making it the most prolific eruption producer in the entire 2,500-km-long Aleutian volcanic chain. Other Alaskan volcanoes may occasionally produce larger individual eruptions — Shishaldin, Cleveland, and Veniaminof are also highly active — but none match Pavlof's eruption frequency over the historical record.

faqs.question: When did Pavlof last erupt?
faqs.answer: Pavlof's most recent eruption began in August 2021 and continued intermittently into 2022. The eruption produced lava fountaining, Strombolian explosions, and ash emissions from summit vents, with ash clouds reaching approximately 4,500-6,000 m (15,000-20,000 ft) altitude. Lava flows descended the northeast and east flanks. The Alaska Volcano Observatory maintained elevated alert levels throughout the eruption. Prior to this, Pavlof had erupted in 2016 (VEI 2), 2014 (two VEI 3 events), and 2013 (VEI 3).

faqs.question: Why is Pavlof dangerous for air travel?
faqs.answer: Pavlof lies directly beneath the North Pacific Great Circle air routes — the shortest flight paths connecting major North American cities to East Asian destinations like Tokyo, Seoul, and Shanghai. Approximately 50,000 commercial flights per year traverse this airspace. Volcanic ash at cruising altitudes (9,000-12,000 m) can cause catastrophic engine failure in jet aircraft. Pavlof's frequent eruptions produce ash columns that regularly reach these altitudes, triggering aviation advisories, flight reroutings, and occasionally temporary closures of portions of North Pacific airspace. The volcano's tendency for rapid-onset eruptions compounds the challenge, as ash can reach flight levels before warnings are issued.

faqs.question: Where is Pavlof Volcano?
faqs.answer: Pavlof is located on the Alaska Peninsula in southwestern Alaska, United States, at coordinates 55.417 N, 161.894 W. It lies approximately 950 km (590 mi) southwest of Anchorage, roughly 60 km northeast of the community of Cold Bay, and about 50 km north of King Cove. The volcano overlooks Pavlof Bay to the south and faces the Bering Sea to the north. It is part of the Aleutian volcanic arc, which stretches 2,500 km from mainland Alaska through the Aleutian Islands.

faqs.question: How tall is Pavlof Volcano?
faqs.answer: Pavlof rises to 2,493 m (8,179 ft) above sea level, making it one of the taller volcanoes on the Alaska Peninsula. Its neighboring cone, Pavlof Sister, stands at 2,142 m (7,028 ft). Shishaldin, located approximately 90 km to the southwest on Unimak Island, is taller at 2,857 m (9,373 ft) and is the highest peak in the Aleutian Islands. Pavlof's effective visual prominence is enhanced by its nearly perfect conical symmetry and its rise from near-sea-level coastal lowlands.

faqs.question: Has Pavlof Volcano killed anyone?
faqs.answer: No fatalities have been recorded from any of Pavlof's 48 historical eruptions. This is primarily due to the volcano's extreme remoteness — the nearest community, Cold Bay, has approximately 100 residents and lies 60 km away. The surrounding Alaska Peninsula landscape is sparsely inhabited tundra and coastal wetland within the Alaska Peninsula National Wildlife Refuge. While Pavlof's eruptions generate significant hazards including pyroclastic flows, lahars, and heavy ashfall, these impacts are contained within largely uninhabited terrain.

faqs.question: What type of eruptions does Pavlof produce?
faqs.answer: Pavlof typically produces Strombolian to Vulcanian eruptions from summit vents on the north and east sides of the cone. These eruptions involve lava fountaining (jets of incandescent molten rock), explosive bursts that send ash columns to altitudes of 5,000-12,000 m (15,000-40,000 ft), lava flows that descend the glacier-covered flanks, and lahars generated when hot volcanic material melts snow and ice. Most eruptions are rated VEI 2-3, lasting days to weeks. The largest recorded eruption (1762-1786) reached VEI 4. Pavlof does not produce the sustained Plinian eruption columns associated with more explosive volcanoes.

faqs.question: Can you visit Pavlof Volcano?
faqs.answer: Visiting Pavlof is possible but requires a serious wilderness expedition. There are no trails, roads, or facilities near the volcano. Access is by bush plane or boat to the Alaska Peninsula, followed by overland travel across roadless tundra. The nearest community with scheduled air service is Cold Bay, about 60 km away, with irregular flights from Anchorage. The volcano lies within the Alaska Peninsula National Wildlife Refuge. Most people who see Pavlof do so from scenic flights or fishing boats in Pavlof Bay. The combination of extreme weather, glacier travel, active volcanic hazards, and brown bear presence makes ground access suitable only for experienced expeditionary teams.

faqs.question: How often does Pavlof erupt?
faqs.answer: Pavlof erupts remarkably frequently — 48 times since 1762, averaging roughly one eruption every 5.4 years. In the 20th century alone, 27 eruptions were recorded, and the 21st century has already seen 10 eruptions in just over two decades. The volcano has produced four separate eruptions since 2013 alone. These eruptions are generally moderate in scale (VEI 2-3) and last days to weeks, though some episodes have persisted for years. Pavlof rarely goes more than a decade without an eruption, making it one of the most consistently active volcanoes in North America.

faqs.question: What is Pavlof Sister?
faqs.answer: Pavlof Sister is a stratovolcano standing at 2,142 m (7,028 ft), located approximately 10 km northeast of Pavlof along the same structural vent lineament. Despite its nearly identical appearance — a symmetrical, glacier-clad cone — Pavlof Sister is far less active than Pavlof and has not produced any historically recorded eruptions. The two volcanoes form one of the most visually dramatic volcano pairs in the world, often photographed together as nearly mirror-image cones rising above the Alaska Peninsula landscape. The reason for the stark difference in activity between the virtually adjacent twins is not fully understood.
